citation.article-title: Jeotgalicoccus nanhaiensis sp. nov., isolated from intertidal sediment, and emended description of the genus Jeotgalicoccus
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Jeotgalicoccus nanhaiensis sp. nov.

Jeotgalicoccus nanhaiensis (nan.hai.en′sis. N.L. masc. adj. nanhaiensis pertaining to Nanhai, the Chinese name for the South China Sea, the source of the sediment sample from which the type strain was isolated).
Cells are Gram-positive-staining, non-motile, non-sporulating, strictly aerobic, catalase- and oxidase-positive, coccus-shaped, 0.7–1.1 µm in diameter and occur singly or in pairs, tetrads or clumps.
Colonies are creamy white, circular, somewhat convex, non-translucent, have glistening surfaces and entire margins and are 1–2 mm in diameter on marine agar 2216 (Difco).
No diffusible pigments are produced.
Growth occurs in the presence of 0.5–25 % (w/v) NaCl (optimally at 2–5 %) and at 4–45 °C (optimally at 30–35 °C) and at pH 5.5–10.5 (optimally at pH 7.0–8.0).
Negative result in methyl red and Voges–Proskauer tests.
Negative results in tests for the decomposition of aesculin, casein, DNA, gelatin, hypoxanthine, starch, Tweens 20, 40, 60 and 80 and xanthine.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
H2S and indole are not produced.
The following compounds are utilized as sole sources of carbon and energy: acetic acid, arbutin, glycerol and myo-inositol.

The following compounds are not utilized: l-arabinose, cellobiose, d-fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, glycogen, lactose, maltose, d-mannose, melezitose, melibiose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, d-ribose, sucrose, trehalose, d-xylose, adonitol, d-mannitol, d-sorbitol, salicin, butyrate, citrate, formate, fumarate, gluconate, malate, malonate, propionate, succinate, l-alanine, l-arginine, l-asparagine, l-glutamic acid, l-glycine, l-histidine, hydroxy-l-proline, l-isoleucine, l-leucine, l-methionine, l-proline, l-serine and l-valine.

Produces acid from d-fructose, d-glucose, maltose, d-mannose, l-rhamnose, d-ribose, sucrose, trehalose, d-xylose, glycerol and d-mannitol, but not from N-acetylglucosamine, l-arabinose, cellobiose, d-galactose, lactose, melezitose, melibiose, raffinose, starch, adonitol, dulcitol, myo-inositol, d-salicin, d-sorbitol and xylitol.
Constitutive enzymes expressed are N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, cystine arylamidase, α-fucosidase, α- and β-galactosidase, α- and β-glucosidase, β-glucuronidase, lipase (C14) and trypsin.

Acid phosphatase, alkaline phosphatase, α-chymotrypsin, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, lysine decarboxylase, α-mannosidase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, ornithine decarboxylase, phenylalanine deaminase, valine arylamidase and urease are not observed.
The major amino acid constituents of the cell wall are alanine, glycine and lysine.
Possesses MK-7 and MK-6 as the predominant menaquinones.
Polar lipids comprise diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol and an unidentified phospholipid.
The major cellular fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0 and iso-C15 : 0.
The type strain, JSM 077023T ( = DSM 23006T = KCTC 13714T), was isolated from an intertidal sediment sample collected from Naozhou Island in the South China Sea, China.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 41.3 mol% (HPLC method).
